abstract.p: Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare skin disorder of zinc deficiency. This case report describes a 91-year-old female nursing home resident who presented with a skin eruption resembling acrodermatitis enteropathica while receiving adequate enteral nutrition (EN) via a percutaneous gastrostomy tube. A low zinc level of 36 mcg/dL confirmed zinc deficiency, and treatment with oral zinc sulfate 220 mg 3 times a day resulted in rapid resolution of the skin lesions. This case supports the notion of close monitoring of patients on long-term EN for clinical manifestations of zinc deficiency, especially in the presence of an unexplained skin rash. Although micronutrient deficiencies are more prevalent in underdeveloped countries and with patients receiving parenteral nutrition, these deficiencies should be kept in mind for patients in developed countries as well as patients receiving EN.

sec.title: Clinical Relevancy Statement
sec.p: This case report shows that a zinc deficiency may arise even if patients are receiving adequate enteral nutrition (EN). Zinc deficiency may lead to complications such as acrodermatitis enteropathica. Monitoring micronutrient levels in patients receiving long-term EN may aid in the identification of deficiencies early enough to avoid the consequences that can arise from them.

sec.title: Case Presentation
sec.p: A 91-year-old female nursing home resident with a medical history of chronic renal insufficiency, pulmonary hypertension, hyperlipidemia, dementia, coronary artery disease, respiratory failure status post tracheostomy, multiple decubitus ulcers, and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement approximately 2 years prior was admitted for evaluation of acral, periorificial, and perineal dermatitis. Six days before admission, the patient was given sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim for an infected right toe ulcer, and that treatment was discontinued 2 days before admission because of a presumed allergic reaction that caused a rash/lesion.

The patient had a history of allergy to penicillin, and her nursing home medications included clopidogrel, escitalopram, lansoprazole, simvastatin, ascorbic acid, metoprolol tartrate, cholecalciferol, docusate sodium, aspirin, and isosorbide dinitrate. Her nutrition regimen at the nursing home consisted of Jevity 1.2 Cal (Abbott Nutrition, Columbus, OH) via PEG at a rate of 50 mL/h for 20 hours per day (1200 kcal, 55.5 g protein, 169.4 g carbohydrates, 39.3 g fat, 810 mL water, 23 mg zinc) and 30 mL Pro-Stat (Medical Nutrition, Englewood, NJ) via PEG 3 times per day (303 kcal, 45 g protein), for a daily total of 1503 kcal and 100.5 g protein. She weighed 73.6 kg, was 64 inches tall, and had a body mass index of 27.8 kg/m2. Her ideal body weight (IBW) was 55 kg, and based on her daily caloric intake, she was receiving 22 kcal/kg IBW.

On the second day post admission, the dermatology and nutrition support teams were consulted. Upon physical examination, the patient’s cutaneous manifestations were characterized by well-demarcated, erythematous, eroded plaques with desquamation. On the patient’s palms, soles, anogenital region, and axilla, scaling skin covered the underlying bloody viable dermis (Figures 1 and 2). No oral mucosal involvement, alopecia, or evidence of photophobia was noted. All laboratory test results were within normal limits, and based on the clinical evidence, a diagnosis of acrodermatitis enteropathica (AE) was considered.

caption.p: Acquired zinc deficiency demonstrated by erythema and superficial desquamation of the feet.
Acrodermatitis enteropathica (acquired zinc deficiency) with acral erythema and bullous lesions.

sec.p: At the time of diagnosis, we drew blood to measure the patient’s baseline zinc level and began empirical zinc sulfate supplementation via PEG at 220 mg (50 mg elemental zinc per tablet) 3 times per day. Fluconazole therapy (150 mg/d for 3 days) was added empirically via PEG to treat Candida albicans, as the lesions were most prevalent in the intertriginous areas. One day later, we received the results of the patient’s pretreatment baseline serum zinc levels (36 mcg/dL; normal range, 60–130 mcg/dL). Five days post treatment, the patient’s serum zinc level was 119 mcg/dL, and 1 week post treatment, her skin lesions had resolved completely, with only postinflammatory hyperpigmentation remaining.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: AE is a zinc deficiency disorder characterized by well-demarcated, pustular and bullous dermatitis in the periorificial and acral regions.1 Hereditary and acquired forms of this condition have been described, and the usual presentations include eczematous and scaly plaques on the face, scalp, acral, and anogenital regions; generalized alopecia; and glossitis.2 AE has been reported in patients receiving parenteral nutrition (PN) therapy but is less common in patients receiving long-term enteral nutrition (EN).3,4 Acquired zinc deficiency secondary to chronic pancreatitis, Crohn’s disease, Whipple procedure, chemotherapy, and essential fatty acid (EFA) deficiency can also present with AE.5-10 Although zinc deficiency has been linked to AE, AE has also been reported in patients with normal serum zinc levels.11 AE generally responds to zinc supplementation within a few days. In cases of inadequate response, deficiencies of other trace elements, amino acids, and EFAs should be considered.12-14

Zinc is an essential trace element that is an integral part of many enzyme systems, including carbonic anhydrase, alkaline phosphatase (ALKP), and DNA polymerases.15 ALKP is a zinc-dependent enzyme, and as suggested by Weismann and Høyer,16 we checked the patient’s serial ALKP levels. At baseline, her ALKP level was 60 units/L (normal range, 40–150 units/L), and 7 days later, the ALKP level had increased to 105 units/L, correlating with the increase in zinc level.

A thorough review revealed that none of the patient’s current medications were causing the zinc deficiency. In addition, she was receiving 1 L of Jevity 1.2 Cal per day, which contains 23 mg of zinc. According to the Institute of Medicine,17 the dietary reference intake of zinc for females older than 70 years is 8 mg/d. Although it may seem as if our patient was receiving a large amount of zinc, the bioavailability of elemental zinc is about 20%, and hence it is possible that our patient required additional zinc supplementation.18 In addition, our patient had no gastrointestinal losses or any other potential losses of zinc, which could be seen through diarrhea, sweat, or burns.

Although zinc deficiency can have many causes, we ruled out medications and fluid losses, among others. The patient’s EN formula contents and the low bioavailability of zinc, her clinical presentation of low serum zinc level, and her response to zinc therapy were all consistent with AE. Nutrition deficiency can present with various cutaneous manifestations and sometimes has intermingling features from different nutrition dermatoses. The diagnosis of AE should be based on the clinical evidence as well as the judgment of the healthcare professionals caring for the patient. Clinicians should monitor micronutrient levels and consider deficiencies in patients receiving long-term EN therapy.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The provision of long-term EN, especially with formulas that are high in fiber and iron, may lead to zinc deficiency. Clinicians should consider monitoring zinc levels in patients receiving long-term EN therapy.
